@aaronsibarium @njhochman I welcome efforts to try to recruit Republicans for civil service jobs. I wonder if there are public-spirited people eager to do the work at least as well as the Democratic majority doing it now. (Did Bush 43 & 41, and Reagan admins complain about being thwarted by bureaucrats?)

@aaronsibarium @njhochman I will grant that trying to run a government overseeing 330 million people is complex, and so that public comment portion of the process might not be ideal. But what *is* ideal? What would be better? Just having the executive branch impose and cancel regs at whim?

@njhochman (I'm going to have to step away here in a minute, so if I go silent, I didn't slink away in a huff.) Again, you would need to point to specific incidents. The process of change is very slow, and it should be. CJ Roberts, for example, is a stickler for this stuff.

@njhochman @aaronsibarium It depends on what you're talking about. Obama also ran into frustrations with the slow pace of implementing regulations to his liking. It takes years, and there are court challenges -- in his case, from conservatives. That's how you run a responsible government.

@njhochman "The people" are sovereign, not "a people," meaning whichever plurality (or even minority) happens to capture the WH at any given time. You need a professional civil service in a modern state. It requires knowledge and expertise. There's no getting around that.
@polanskydj @Amb8819 https://t.co/LDMCIxRm0j

@aaronsibarium @njhochman I think it could be improved in various ways and would support some forms of reforms, but I don't think this is a partisan problem. It's not that it systematically does progressive things. It does what Congress asks it to do, after a long, arduous process of public comment.

@njhochman Of course you (or a president) can object. But then you follow a process. You don't just fire the top eight layers as the Department of Education and replace them with people who will do the president's bidding without going through the arduous process of public review.

@aaronsibarium @Amb8819 I will admit that I used Nate's tweet as a jump off to take aim at something commonly heard on the right these days. If he favors piecemeal reform of the federal civil service to improve it, I say bravo. But that presumes the legitimacy of the federal civil service.
@njhochman I bet if you think something violates the Constitution, someone else disagrees. How is that resolved? By court challenge. That's how you run a country of 330 million people.

@gpurcell No, "it" does what Congress and the person running the executive branch tell it to do, unless what it's told contradicts something else it's been told, requiring resolution. Every modern democracy has a civil service.
@Amb8819 That's an argument for reform, not the deconstruction the right seems excited bout.
@tkdylan Then criticize Congress, not the bureaucrats.

1. The "admin state" (professional civil service) does nothing Congress doesn't empower it to do.

2. Everything it does passes through a long process of public review & comment.

3. Anything it does can be challenged in court.

@SunnyDfan4eva @rb2bb @jennfrey It isn't a supernatural ability. It's a natural human ability that can't be replicated by a non-biological computer. I've now elaborated my position in this thread: 

https://t.co/B1f3o4Rcli

And that means: The only way to create consciousness is to create ... a human being or other life form very much like a human being. We already do that, of course, whenever we have children. Why seek to do it artificially? What would be the advantage of that? 10/10
And it couldn't just be a brain in a vat. It would need a body to move through physical space -- a body with needs/goods/vulnerability that drives it intentionally through the world. 9/10

In other words, the computer just needs to have 1 & 2 above & a high processing capacity. But 3 is just as necessary. Which means that we would need to create a biological (or "wet) computer, i.e., a living brain. 8/10

My point is this: Those seeking to create artificial life tend to think consciousness is the brain modeled on a computer. We just need to develop a computer complex and fast enough to handle sufficient numbers of calculations. 7/10

If someone harms me (transgresses my good), I feel wronged, become angry in self-defense, and use reason to explain why that's bad in order to justify my urge to harm the transgressor in retaliation. Morality arises from such justifications. 6/10
Moral ideas (and along with them the sense of the meaningfulness of experience, why things matter to us, have gravity, etc.) emerge from this perception of one's own good and ideas about it: 5/10

Consciousness as human beings experience it requires all three elements working in tandem. That is what generates: imagination; ideas about the good, including a sense of one's own good expanding to cover one's family, village, city, country, the world as a whole, etc.; 4/10

3. Biological drives, especially each organism's drive for its own good or flourishing: self-preservation, food, drink, sex, etc. This concern for one's own good becomes intentional, goal-directed activity in the world. 3/10

Consciousness blends 3 things:
1. Sense perception: colors, shapes, sounds, textures, etc.
2. Reasoning, especially the categorization of those perceptions into kinds (what the ancient philosophers called "forms"): person, tree, dog, car, lake, grass, house, etc. 2/10

This seems as good a time as any to explain why I don't think human beings will ever -- that's right, ever -- manage to create artificial life w consciousness as we understand & live it. This sweeping statement has one caveat, which I will note at the end of a short thread. 1/10
@SunnyDfan4eva @jennfrey Which means: We would need to create something very much like ... a living, breathing human being.

@SunnyDfan4eva @jennfrey I think that is quite wrong. Consciousness is a blend of sense perception, reasoning (e.g., categorizing perceptions into kinds), and (crucially for this subject) biological drives, including a drive for one's own good. To attain consciousness, a robot would need to be organic.

@jennfrey I'd be more concerned if the robot actually felt emotions, but of course it doesn't. A human being is making it look like it feels them. I'm pretty firmly convinced that a non-biological entity will never achieve consciousness (and thus experience & feeling) as we understand it.
